author: Frugalshave

description.text: MishaT's well-known Nautilus Gears, re-drawn for laser cutting rather than printing, and with a simple motorised display stand.

Plain laser cutting, although you will need clean cuts as the septa in the nautilus are quite thin.  
For basic gears, just cut the left hand gear from page #1.  Page #2 is a simple display stand for them, using bamboo barbecue skewers as axles.  
Motorised display is on #3. This is a stand for one of the cheap and common geared motors. I used 200:1 reduction, but the 120:1 are maybe a bit quieter.  It would be nice to add PIR sensor triggering too.  
Use one of the right-hand nautilus gears to fit the motor shaft  
The stand is straightforward laser-cut mortice and tenon joinery, but slightly tapered. It's drawn to cut from 3mm MDF. The front panel also has a useful and re-usable layout for mounting these motors.   
There are two front panels, the slightly larger one is a false front to cover the screw heads and the wood joints. As I didn't have any countersunk screws (M3 x 25) handy, I cut a couple of ugly holes in here at the last moment to give screw head clearance. If you countersink the screws into the inner panel, you could avoid this!  
Small 2×AA battery box inside, just wedged into place against the motor. The oval hole in the back panel accesses the switch.  
Once you've made the inner stand, wrap the living hinge outer wrapper around it and clamp into place while the glue sets. This uses the hinge pattern from MSRaynsford's ring box, slightly stretched onto the taper.  
Be careful pressing the gear onto the motor, it's a tight fit and they're fragile!  
Corel Draw and PDF formats.  Mostly just cut the black lines and ignore the red lines, as they're only construction lines.

I designed this because after a days fishing, I remove the hook and line from the reel line and just put it back into my tackle box. it usually gets tangled with the others and I end up throwing them away. I made a wooden block to wind them round and cut a notch to secure the line, that works fine but I thought a 3D printed version would be far more slick so here it is. The notch for the line is 0.2mm wide, so I found I had to open it up with a knife, my tackle box is really tidy now.
A not to scale replica of SpaceX's Falcon 9 Rocket

While building larger structures with struts and joints like these:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9359 I find that I need some more tesselation of the structure. This set of things forms a simple joint which allows you to easily form more triangles within the boundaries of your structures. Of course you can do a whole lot more than just form more triangles, but that was the initial intent. These things derive from a couple of things:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8130
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8129 If you're doing a permanent structure, you could still use thing 8129, and stick a 1/8" pin into the hole. There are a couple of key design aspects to these things.
1) They are symmetrically paired, which means you can place two next to each other (the 'half' form) and they will allow their struts to be at the same level. In fact, the interlocking nature of the pieces ensures that once you have two collars on the rod, they will not slip easily. That alleviates the need for any type of fastener for simple installations. 2) They use nipples and dimples for grabbing. So, you don't need any extra hardware to bring the parts together. No nuts and screws to fiddle with. There is a notch on both sides of the receiver to help facilitate sliding the nippled grabber into place. You can fiddle with the depth of those notches, or eliminate them completely if you find you don't need them. If you have enough of these placed around your structure, a plain wooden structure suddenly becomes strong enough to hold a blanket on top (on a dodecahedron with 36" struts). If you are using shorter struts, like 24", then you probably don't need these to reinforce the corners, but can do other things instead. The connoisseur of platonic solids, and other forms of interesting solids, will recognize the fact that truncated forms are easily formed using this system. Just don't use the stellated vertices, move these to the ends of the struts, put a cap on it, and there you have it! At least for some forms. At any rate, you might find some use for this set if you're into building things with sticks.

1) Print equal numbers of receivers, and grabbers.
2) Slide a couple onto each end of a strut
3) Slide shorter struts into these for support, or whatever
4) Rejoice! By default, these pieces fit on 5/16" wood dowels. You can easily change that by changing the gRodIR parameter in the file, and regenerate. The fit is relatively loose (10% larger than radius). If you want a more snug fit, make that more like 5% (smaller if you want it to be downright hard to move). The best plan for keeping them in place, with friction, is to just put some blue tape on the rod at the point where you want it to stick, which will thicken it up just enough at that point. If you want a permanent fit, then put a dab of glue in place right before you slide the piece over it, and that's that.

remixed_from.title: Tower Simple XL, building a 3D Printer under 200$

description.text:
Collection of stand-offs and misc metric sized parts that were difficult for me to source in North America. If you have access to a 3D printer (I printed these at my local library!) these are quick to print and fit well.

Z-Axis 60mm End-stop Post: Fits to the YZ axis arm at the back. Don't forget an M3 8mm spring for fine adjustments

M3 6mm Nylon Standoff: Not in this collection (was able to source locally) isn't mentioned in the Instructable but in order to fit the LCD panel to the control box you'll need some 6mm stand-offs. Very tight clearance in this entire printer design (notice the LCD connectors bumping right up to the DRV88 boards)

Arduino stand-offs: Might not be necessary if you can find 4-40 8mm stand-offs (I couldn't) M2.5 6mm screws on the top secure to the Arduino Mega, M3 10mm pan-head screws attach the stand-offs to the bottom of the box

X-Axis Bed Stand-offs: For the bed-leveling springs. Uses 4 M3 10mm screws.

Filament Roll Holders: Couldn't find the exact metric sized PVC tube needed to fit the bearings in Canada, so I just 3D printed it!

This things intend is to keep board game cards in order during play and to store them safely the rest of the time.  
The holder can be completely customized to fit stacks of cards of any dimension. Multiple holders can be stacked safely by using the build in rails.

To customize this thing to your needs please use the "open in customizer" button on this page or OpenSCAD. The tab "primary parameters" should contain all parameters needed. Due to the sliding parts the default parameters might not be sufficient on some printers. Should printed holders or lids fit too tightly try increasing the "fudge factor" parameter, should they fit too loose try decreasing it. Should this not solve the problem try manipulating specific settings in the "secondary parameters" tab. Perfectly printed holders / lids should slide without much resistance into each other and snap in when almost fully inserted. I'm printing on an Ultimaker and use Cura with the following parameters. These parameters haven't been really optimized for this thing (meaning faster speeds will probably just work as well).
  • wall thickness: 0.4
  • layer height: 0.2
  • bottom/top thickness: 0.6
  • print speed: 50mm/s
  • bridge speed: 50%

comments.text: Why is the box body oriented the way it is?  I understand why it needs to be printed vertically, but as it is you need to have support for a whole side of it.  I turned it 180° so it only needed to support the sides around where the cutout is, and it seems to be just fine, and probably saved a lot of time.

comments.text: I have to ask, I'm pretty new at 3D printing myself, why would it "need" to be printed vertically? I know that Cura tells me I can cut off roughly 1/3 of the print time by laying it down instead...
comments.author: clsn

comments.text: For most printers the standard rotation should work best due to the rails not needing any support and thus create a flatter surface for the lid to slide into. If your printer somehow can manage without support or you remove the support very cleanly the normal rotation might just work. Just give it a try and tell me about it :)
comments.author: ymerejo42

comments.text: I picked the rotation to enable printing without any support at all which at least for me worked fine, however, a little cleanup with a knife is usually needed to remove the stringing at the top. YMMV.
comments.author: clsn

comments.text:
Huh. I figured it would need support for that big vast top; I didn't even try without. But I'm new at this, and my intuitions regarding when support is necessary are really lousy. Also, I'm printing for full-sized poker decks, which are larger than the default measurements in the OpenSCAD file at least (and thus maybe larger than the cards you commonly print for); that might make a difference.
A downside to support is that it can leave little rough remnants on the inside (doesn't always snap off cleanly); there are a few spots in particular that are always there. Not serious, but if they're collector's decks or something and you want to make sure not to damage the box you have to be careful
Thanks!

author: kennywutang41

description.text:
Make it out of wood!
It's faster, cheaper and most likely stronger... However, for those of us with no immediate/easy acces to plywood and/or no workshop for production our tabletop printer saves the day!

This is meant to fit the foam plane "swappable build kits" from FliteTest.

Motormount holes are for 12/16mm spacing (For example DYS1806).
There is one version for 5mm motormount screws and a version with spacers for 7mm screws (in case you used up all your 5's as I did...)

Let me know if your need one for 16/19mm spacing.
It is used as a firewall/motormount in the part FliteTest sometimes refer to as the "PowerPod". Anyway, if you found this "thing" here you probably know what you are looking for ;)

There are 3 holes for the barbecue skewers so that you can use it for both single-centered and 2-skewer setups (check the pictures of my prototypes).

I have to thank www.flitetest.com for starting my interest - it's a truly great team of people, all of them very inspiring. Support FliteTest and have a nice flight :)

Motormount spacing: 12mm and 16mm
Diameter of holes for skewers: 4mm

This is simply an extra few bits for KyroPaul's odometer.  
The window bit acts as a gentle spring to stop the wheels over- rotating and they also provide a hole through which to view the number.  
The cogs file is a plate of the main wheels already assembled, instead of being printed in three parts that you have to put together yourself.  
The axels are just axels - print them diagonally across your plate for strength, push them through (you will have to drill out all the holes to make things spin easily) and then cut them to length when you're finished.  
The numbers are created on a Dymo Letratag label printer large size font, vertical alignment with two spaces between each number and then just wrapped round the cogs - a perfect fit (hint: enter the numbers 0, 9, 8, 7 etc)

You'll need to download the box and other cogs from KyroPaul's thing - 90076.  
Glue the windows/spring things in place with some acetone/filament scraps glue making sure they aren't holding the cogs too tight.

description.text:
Hi,
I have created a Customized a version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:28405 to use as a tensile strength test for your filament and printer settings.

I printed this link 50mm long with 25% fill and 0.3mm layer height in PLA PETG ABS and Nylon.

Then used a very crude test to pull tension on the links.

PETG carried 10KG ok then catastrophically failed at 20KG
PLA carried 20KG ok then delaminated at 30KG
ABS carried 30KG ok the 40KG caused cracks on corners
Nylon carried 60KG ok then went on to hold 120KG looking like it could possibly take more.

Enjoy your own tests.

author: josepha48

title: DIY Air Freshener lid for 8oz Ball quilted crystal jelly jars

description.text:
There is a product known by several names like water marbles, crystal mud and such. These are tiny polymer beads (smaller than a BB) that when soaked in water grow around 10x there size as they soak in the water, over time, the water will evaporate and they will shrink again but it takes weeks or even a month.

I saw that some people were using these with water that also had a fragrance mixed in (water soluble fragrance) and they used them as air fresheners. So I decided to do this and I made this lid system that the openings can be varied for different amounts of fragrance.

Please read the Instructions page for specifics.

I prefer printing these in ABS but you can print them in whatever you like, if not ABS though you will need to glue the parts together.

Print out at any resolution you desire. Print at least 2 of the pins at a time to prevent distortion from heat since they are tiny and the tallest object.

Once printed, insert the pin into the largest piece (top) and then into the next one (top spin) and then put a drop of acetone (for ABS only) onto the bottom of the knob and shake away any excess, then place the knob onto the pin and press down until it's got good contact with the top plate. Twist the top and bottom plates to assure they move, there should be a little friction.

Set it aside and wait for the ABS to evaporate and it's ready to use.

The crystal marbles need to soak in a mixture of fragrance and water (depending on how strong your fragrance is, it may be a 50:1 mix) for 12 or more hours, then drain off the excess liquid and place the marbles in the jar with the new lid in place and open to the desired amount.

title: Cyvasse playing board for dual extruders
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Dutchmogul's beautiful and inspiring Cyvasse set was crying out for a dualstrusion playing board.

boardplatemajorsquares.stl contains the base plate and the "major" raised squares.  Merge this with boardminorsquares.stl for two of the four builds.  Merge boardplateminorsquares.stl with boardmajorsquares.stl for the other two builds.  You'll end up with a 10x10 board with alternating color squares, perfect for Cyvasse.  
Printed on a MBI Replicator dual extruder, Sailfish firmware, ReplicatorG 40r17 Sailfish, Skeinforge 50 with PyPy, 1.8mm black and white ABS filament from MBI, .17mm layer height, 110C HBP, 230C left and right extruders, 10% infill, 1 shell.  
I'm open to suggestions on how to resolve a flaw in the way the stls merge.  The bottom layer of the free-floating squares seems to coincide with the top layer of the base plates.  This causes my nozzle printing the free-floating squares to jam for that Z position.  If I babysit the print and unjam the second nozzle once the build platform moves down a layer, all is mostly well.  The white squares still suffer somewhat when the black nozzle scrapes across their surface.  I hope to find (or code) a Skeinforge module to restrict the build order of individual islands to avoid nozzle dragging.

title: Part for Spool and Tool Hanger Above Work Bench

description.text:
Hangs a dowel out and away from shelf to present occasionally - but regularly - used items that clutter workspace.  Took all of about 20 minutes to design it, it took about 50 minutes to extrude each part - 3 parts were used to hold up a 4 foot dowel.
"Smaller Shelf" version is for a wire shelf that has a 3/4" wire rod gap versus the pictured shelf that has a wire gap of 1 1/4".  Make sure to use the correct one.
Both versions will accept normal wire spools up to 2" in radius.

Uses wire shelf system(s) commonly found at Home Depot.  Just snaps in place with a little force and the weight of the dowel assists in holding it there.
Dowel is wood and 15mm in diameter.  FAMULUS used a copper pipe, and this seemed to work well too.
When extruding, I recommend utilizing a 100% fill, versus a sparse fill - this will make the part stronger.

author: hjbinnema

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/3E1ZlhLlvm7

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_KCvDN2CBWw

These are the files for the Drone Trophy, designed by Noe Ruiz and Bruce Yan. "Dronie" is a friendly, cuddly gumdrop looking cartoon. These parts were designed to print in metal filament. Parts are separated into pieces so they can fit inside rotary tumbler.

The parts have a snap fit design that has loose tolerance to compensate for expansion when printing with bronzeFill.

I sliced these parts with a bit more infill and outline overlap. Extra top and bottoms layers help close off the surface while more shells lets the surface withstand hours of tumbling.

Large parts tend to be difficult to remove from the build plate, so I found it easier to use two spatulas. One to peel the corner, and a second one to slide underneath.

Printing at 100 microns on the Type A Machine works really well especially with bronzeFill. I set printing speeds around 40mm/sec to help retain surface quality.

Some parts are of course easier to remove than others, so it’s important to do it slowly and carefully. Because, you know - it can be a little dangerous, you could break the part or hurt yourself - so be careful

These parts tend to come out with stringy bits due to retraction and oozing, but this can easily be cleaned up using diagonal flush snips and a hobby knife to get in between all the nooks and crannies.

I let the parts tumble for about 1-2 hours and used stainless steel screws as the medium. Using different sized screws actually help polish the smaller details.

The parts came out looking polished and have that bronze cast look. They’re really shiny and feels just like metal - the weight of this stuff is so cool.

For making the prop bits, we actually used the Ember Printer from Autodesk. These tiny parts are perfect for DLP,SLA printers and they came out with amazing detail in clear resin.

To secure the tower piece to the base of the trophy, I used E600 to bond them together.

The bottom part has recessed fittings for the prop arms, and they just snap into place.

The tolerances came out pretty good with an offset of 0.4mm, which gives it a slight snap fit.

A bit of E6000 adhesive will permanently bond these parts together. I used a clamp that locks to hold it tightly in place while I let the adhesive cure.

For the propellers, we wanted them actually spin, so I had to designed it in several parts.

The prop piece has a hole in the middle, so a studding can be inserted and held in place with a lock nut - The studding piece has a cap on top.

There’s a cavity on the bottom of the arm for the lock nut to snap into, and we’ll just glue it in place - And thats how to make the props freely spin.

I thought i’d be cool to use magnets so the Dronie could come off the trophy base. This give it to have a bit of freedom, which I think it's pretty cool.

The magnets loosely fit into the parts and are held in place with E600.

And now we have Dronie - A 3D printed Trophy in metal filament.

So, If you’re thinking about using metal filaments in your next 3d printed project, check out this stuff from colorFabb!

description.text: My first creation, I made this measure tool to reduce the need to use a tape measure. Its easier to use in smaller spaces.

title: Fountain Pen Rest (one piece, no supports)

description.text:
I use fountain pens and I don't want them rattling around loose in a pencil can or on the desk where they pick up scratches. I also want them at a slight downward angle to prevent bubbles from getting stuck at the tank exit, causing feed problems when I go to write.

I didn't like any of the existing pen rests/holders, so I cranked this one out this afternoon and printed it. I've had this exact item imagined for many months but only just now got a 3D printer to make it a reality.

As usual, use this design at your own risk, I am not responsible for any damages or injuries that may result from using these parts.

I printed this on my XYZ Da Vinci 1.0 in about 3.5 hours, using 16m of filament with a 10% infill. Print this on its side (in a Z shape looking down) and it will easily print without supports.

After printing, I leveled the feet with a little sanding, then added a layer of self-adhesive felt I picked up at the local craft superstore for a few bucks.

Classic foldable/hinged sewing box (notions box).

Here's an animated GIF of the box in action!

Work in progress—what you see is the current beta.

See "Instructions" for BOM.

Since I assumed incorrect values for the width of the sex bolts' barrel, my proof-of-concept is—as you can see in the pictures—a bit crooked! Also, lids are missing at the moment…
Working on fixing it soon! ^^

Bill of materials:

  • the (wood-)cut parts
    The design assumes 3mm; I used HDF.
  • wood glue
    Still trying to figure out some clamping mechanism to avoid using (too much) glue
  • 28 sex bolts (aka binder screws, screw posts, or Chicago screws)
    Their barrel length should be (at least) twice your material's thickness (which means that the design, as it is, calls for 6mm screws).

Work in progress

What you see is the current beta. Of note:

  • erroneously assumed wrong measurements, so the holes for the sex bolts are too wide (6mm instead of 4mm), thus making the box (surprisingly) crooked; need to make sure the sex bolts' barrel diameter corresponds to the width of the holes

  • I thought that compartment-overlap might be an issue, so I misimproved it and made that too small (for my tastes anyway; stability might be a non-issue if the holes—see above—were correct)

  • as you might have noticed, there's no lids as of yet. ;-)

Implemented optimisation

Please note: There are micro-optimisations in the SVG!

Although originally intended for the holes of the hinges to be spaced 5cm (horizontally) and 4cm (vertically) apart, I didn't want to use a non-natural number for the spacing of the holes on the hinges. (Pythagoras' theorem with 4 and 5 calls for sqrt(41).)

I looked-up close-by Pythogorean triples and found a decent candidate: (39, 52, 65). That way, the holes on the hinge can be spaced exactly 65mm from one another.

But that's also why the top and bottom drawers have their holes pushed 1mm closer to the center drawer (which has been left untouched), while the "outer" holes (relative to the center hole on each of the two sides of the cubes that form the two halves of the whole thing) have moved 1mm away from the center one.

The math worked out fine, but these considerations have to be taken into account when adapting or altering the design.

description.text:
I remixed mitchr's Spandau model to include a printable barrel shroud. I am building a Flitetest Mini Scout and am planning on modeling it on the Fokker EIII which typically only had a single mounted gun. Later versions had double MGs mounted. If you're printing this for a mighty mini, you'll need to scale it down. If you have trouble printed the vented barrel, there is an stl for a barrel without vents. I have this on the 50% sized version that will be mounted to my mini scout.

I've also included the sketchup file and an stl of just the barrel shroud in case you just want to print the shroud to use on mitchrs design which is great if you want a double MG mount.

The main body has some overhangs and sockets that need support. The barrel shroud and side pieces shouldn't need supports or rafts. Print out the pieces and use a dab of super glue to secure everything.

author: evco

description.text: LogicSupply BeagleBone Black Case Lid

Writeup containing actual links at http://eclecti.cc/hardware/physical-keygen-now-for-disc-detainer-locks The Physical Keygen post got some interesting reactions, but there was a common claim among many of them that it was just a gimmick because there are more practical ways of getting past basic Schlage and Kwikset pin tumbler locks. I agree with that, and Iâ€™ll also admit that a fair number of my projects are gimmicks, or as a stretch, art. Schuyler Towne of Open Locksport saw past the gimmick (or art) and into the possibility of printing keys for more interesting locks. He stopped by recently with a collection of said locks, and over the period of a few hours we found that keys for disc detainer locks were printable and created a nearly working ABUS Plus key. He left me a cutaway lock, and over the next week, I refined the model to the point of working straight off of the printer. Despite being a higher security lock than the SC1 or KW1 pin tumblers I was working with before, the key is much easier to print accurately. The OpenSCAD model is linked below, and like the last files, you simply edit the last line to match the code for your key. The ABUS Plus and other disc detainer locks are much more common in Europe than the US, but we do have a pretty ubiquitous example around here. After the Bic Pen debacle in 2004, Kryptonite switched their bicycle U-locks from tubular to disc detainer. I designed a model off of the key from the Kryptonite Evolution I have, but as of yet, I have not successfully opened the lock with it. The key is smaller and thinner than the ABUS Plus, causing it to flex too much to effectively turn the last few discs. Iâ€™ve posted the file anyway, in case someone has stronger plastic or an idea to strengthen the model. EDIT: The Kryptonite key works. I tightened my X and Y belts and printed it a bit slower. Apparently some of the blobbing on the corners before was catching on disks.

description.text:
For one of my projects I needed to bend a piece of flat Aluminium profile into a circle.

The aluminium sheet comes between the two parts which are then clamped onto the Aluminium, thus forming it.

From the radius I calculated how much Aluminium profile I needed an cut it to that size. I would recommend that you mark your length with a little bit of padding on both sides, because the end pieces do not bend very well.

If you leave some padding you can bend a full circle and than simultaneously cut off both paddings.

The old brain teaser puzzle where you need to jump the pegs one at a time until there is one left.

Description
Base is 6 inches long by .75 inches think
Pegs are 1.5 inches long the upper diameter is .6 inches

Printing Details
I printed everything at .2 mm resolution.
I printed the pegs at 100% infill and the base at 10%
took my printer about 8-10 hours
everything should have no problems fitting together

Let me know if there are issues!

I printed mine with PLA. Support is required.

This little clip is one weapon in my never-ending struggle to not be tripped by my own cables. It also provides a bit of strain relief for long runs by putting the strain from the weight of the cable on the clip/clothing instead of directly on the instrument.

Made with a 6mm outer diameter cable in mind.
Depending on the model this piece can serve as a replacement to hold the toilet paper.
This was made to connect 2 40mm fans for cooling pla prints.

title: Windows Thingiverse Thing Downloader
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Just a few days before feilen posted his "Thingiverse Downloader" @ http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9292 I also started working on a downloader too. Coincidence is an understatement. Big difference is that mine is meant for Windows and runs on the .NET 3.5 Framework. It integrates with Internet Explorer only at this stage via a right-click menu item. The IE add-on communicates with the downloader app (called ThingGeT) via a socket connection which means this app needs to run in the background if you want to download a Thing. This is taken care of by letting the app startup automatically when Windows starts and minimizing it to the system tray. It creates a folder for the thing you're downloading in the configured location and uses the thing's title as the folder name. A shortcut to the thing's page is then created in the folder and all the selected files of the thing will be downloaded and saved to that folder. At the moment it only has one download thread, downloading one file at a time. In the next version I want it to have 2 or 3 concurrent download threads and to display each item's progress inline in the listview box. I am also contemplating adding a downloaded/completed tab where I can move download items to once completed thereby keeping the current downloads list clean. I can then maybe also add functionality to re-download selected items and maybe also allow the user to browse back to the source page of the thing. This version will also not operate behind a proxy server that requires user credentials. The next version will also address such functionality.

• Download and install the setup.
  • Restart Windows when prompted.
  • To configure the download location and other settings open ThingGeT from your system tray (look for a yello & red TG icon in your system tray). Double-click it or right-click ad select Restore. (To minimize back to system tray click the minimize button and not the close button...next version will let it 'close' to the system tray.)
  • Click the Options button to access the configuration settings. Make changes and click Save
  • Open Internet Explorer and go to any Thingiverse Thing page.
  • Right-click on the page and click on Download Thingiverse Thing
  • A dialog box will open where you can change the title the thing will be saved as and you can also select/deselect which of the thing's files you want to download.
  • When ready to download the thing just click the Download button.
  • You will receive a confirmation message that the thing will be downloaded.
  • To view download progress open ThingGeT from your system tray.

description.text:
Printable box for BBP 1 and BBP 1S.
This box including 2 parts: top and buttom.
This is a small door hanger for whatever you want to hang on a door.
The first set of tokens are to facilitate food tracking in the roleplaying game I run. There are 1/2, 1 and 2 denominations, each with the units on the front and a food symbol on the back.

Modeled in Carrara which doesn't export obj that Makerware can use. Normally load in Hexagon and export as STL, but for some reason Hexagon makes a hash of these objects. Instead exported as OBJ which Makerware loads and prints just fine.  
Printed in PLA at 14mm using 3 shells and 25% at the normal .27mm layer height. Bottom ridge is barely reproduced and appear to be some flaws due to the thinness of the token.  
The 4x23 array is arranged to avoid getting too close to the edge as I've had frequent peeling issues at either side. When I printed it the two left most tokens in the front rank were lost (the first at ~75% and the second at ~90%) but the rest came out okay.

description.text:
Easy Print Garmin Edge Bike Mount. Should fit Edge 500, 510, 800 and 810.

31.8mm clamp diameter.

The first iteration didn't survive a road ride, so I made it more beefy.
This one has held up well on a rigid mountain bike over some pretty rough terrain.

-- UPDATE --
Still going strong on my mountain bike, going to might make some additional versions with different offsets for better placement if there is interest.

Rotate to base down and print with settings that work well for your printer.

Be sure to test the strength and tightness of the mount, mine is pretty tight and doesn't budge. I used two hex bolts screwed into the plastic, but made it so longer nuts and bolts could be secured.

description.text:
Generates historic micromouse robotics mazes. These are useful for robotics simulators like V-rep or Gazebo. For more information on micromouse, see the links below.

  • http://web.cecs.pdx.edu/~edam/Reports/2001/DWillardson.pdf
  • http://www.apec-conf.org/conference/participating-in-micromouse/
  • http://www.micromouseonline.com/

A collection of mazes can be found below. These mazes can be copied and pasted into the excel sheet to generate the function calls required to build the maze.

  • https://www.ocf.berkeley.edu/~fricke/projects/micromouse/mazes/

Hey Everyone! Its only taken approximately forever but I finally finished my new direct drive bowden extruder aptly named the "Phantom Extruder" for its remarkable power despite its size and outward appearance. I wanted an extruder that was small and very easy to work on. I also wanted something that was easy to swap out filaments. This extruder does all of this. The MK8 drive gear provides lots of power making this perfect for bowden. If you have any questions or a request for a certain file type feel free to comment below! Thanks for looking!

Here is the link to the video about the extruder:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=B53JddDr31A

UPDATE 8/13/2015: New Direct Drive version with a mount added to the body (EXTRUDER BODY WITH MOUNT). You now no longer need a spacer or 35mm M3 Screws. You should be able to just use 30mm screws. Also added a Direct Drive version that has a mount for an extruder along with the clamp to hold it in (EXTRUDER HOTENDBODY and EXTRUDER HOTEND BODY-HOTEND CLAMP). Its specked for an E3D V6. Also uploaded STEP files so now you can customize everything to your liking!

To assemble this extruder you will need:

-EXTRUDER CLAMP
-EXTRUDER CLAMP PIVOT
-EXTRUDER IDLER BEARING
-EXTRUDER SPRING COMPRESSOR
-one of the extruder bodies
-2 M3X50 S.H.C.S
-3 M3X30 S.H.C.S
-2 M3 nylon lock nuts
-A length of 8mm rod (<20mm in length)
-1 688zz bearing
-MK8 Drive Gear
-1 Nema 17 Motor

Springs are also needed for the inside of the CLAMP piece. I do not have a source for those but they must be less that 20mm in free length and less than 9mm in diameter if you want to look for some.

author: chinna

description.text: 'Real' looking customizable, single-extruder friendly license plate model designed to mimic a Pennsylvania motorcycle license plate.

How to display a name

  • Download and install a license plate looking font. Like-http://www.fontspace.com/category/license%20plate
  • Open stl in OpenScad. Requires version 2015.03.
  • Enter a name to display. Probably, 6 character or less. Play with the spacing value.
  • Enter the exact font name. Notice the names can differ http://i.imgur.com/PZHqaEv.png. In Windows Control Panel > Fonts > Right click on onft > Properties contains the name you need to use in OpenScad.
  • Render and print!

Two-color print

  • To get the two color look you have to change filament to a different color mid-print at 'the magic layer'. Pause the print and switch filaments at the layer in which the lettering and bevel start to be printed. The magic layer will differ on how you slice the stl. Printing at .2mm layer height, layer 9 is where I switch from blue to yellow..

Tip 1 on switching filament- Try to pause the print during the infill of the magic layer. While switching filament you may inadvertently push the nozzle into the print and leave a blemish. It doesn't look good when a hot nozzle is pressed into a visible edge. Ask me how I know...
Tip 2 on switching filament- Be ready to adjust the flow rate when you switch filament. I had quite a difference in diameter between the two spools. Blue was 1.765mm and the yellow measured 1.715. I bumped the flow rate to 125% (max) after observing under-extrusion on the yellow layers.

title: DJI 450 Flame Wheel Quadcopter Folding Leg

description.text:
A folding leg set that fits the DJI 450 Flame Wheel style quadcopter.
This makes storing your machine much easier yet gives clearance of the underside to wet grass etc.

You will require a M4 x 16mm nut and bolt, here in Australia I used a plastic M4 nut and bolt from Jaycar Electronics.
You will also need an M4 tap to cut a thread.
Both of the holes are slightly smaller than required for M4 bolts, the Clamp half I run a drill through it to make the hole neat and de-bur the sunken hole as this is needed to allow the bolt head with No.2 Philips drive.
The leg half (Thicker section) I run the M4 tap through it carefully and slowly, the idea is you do the bolt up firm and use the nut as a locking nut.
I printed this on a Flashforge Dreamer at Standard resolution, use supports for the clamp half as this helps form the sunken screw head hole much neater.
I used PLA, also tried ABS I just preferred the result in PLA, choose any colour you like :-)

author: Georgetheflyingpig

description.text:
UPDATE (June 2017): Added STL file to print two separate antenna boosters.

Using this antenna booster you will extend the maximum range of the Remote Controller of your DJI Phantom 4 / Phantom 3 or Inspire 1 up to 2-3 times!
All you have to do after 3D printing this booster is to cover the front side of the two reflectors with aluminum or copper adhesive foil.
Thanks to the optimized shape of the reflectors, the electromagnetic waves are focused just along the axis of the antennas.

If you own a Phantom 3 Standard or a Phantom 2, please see the following page:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1096728

You can usually get excellent results with the booster covered with aluminium foil, anyway my boosters with copper coating will allow you to reach more distant targets, moreover it can give better results expecially when you pilot your drone in areas with sparse trees and medium size obstacles. In any case, you will be greatly impressed by the improvements that this Range Booster will give to your flights with DJI Phantom or Inspire drones.

A simple replacement for the Odyssey White Ice putter insert.

Remove your old damaged insert by boiling the putter head and prying it out. Print the insert at 100% infill, reduce that a bit to deaden it. Its quick to print and amazing to see how much energy infill can absorb. I made a variation with a thin copper face, I think this is a fun way to test the characteristics of various filaments and infill densities.

title: Customizable device stand (phone, tablet, wireless keyboard, etc.)

description.text:
My first customizable Thing: this stand is a simple double-sided inverted "V" stand for a phone, tablet, keyboard or anything else you want to stand up out of the way when you're not using it.

My default rake values give two options for viewing angle, which work well for my 7" and 8" tablets. It's also perfect for standing my Logitech MK270 wireless keyboard out of the way when I don't need it.

If you're customizing it then be careful to make it large enough to hold your devices without toppling over, but also to keep it within your printable area.

I use 0.2mm layer height, 0.48mm extrusion width, two perimeters and five horizontal shells.

The stand is 2mm thick which is exactly 4 perimeters using the above settings, so it prints very quickly without needing any infill. I find this is strong enough for my purposes but feel free to tweak the SCAD file if you want to make it stronger.

My first ever swimming goggles have been following me for almost two decades before the flexible middle part gave up and started crumbling...

About 18 years ago, I bought myself a pair of swimming goggles. I had bben using them every time I went to the swim, which I did a lot at the time.
As I grew older, I did not use them so much, and they ended up in a drawer.
Until one day, when I was going to the swim again. I picked up by beloved swimming goggles, and they were still looking mighty fine. EXCEPT the little, thingy that goes over the nose, so I decided to enter the design into OpenSCAD.

At first I printed the thing in PLA just to see if I got all the measures correct, then I attached it to the goggles and dipped it into hot water to make the PLA bendable. Looks good, but the PLA i a bit too brittle, that's why I went on and printed it with flex filament - it fits excactly like the original part and it shall be exciting to see how long this one will last - anyway, now I can always just print another.

I have provided the OpenSCAD source just in case anybody wants to tinker and make one to fit their own swimming goggles.
Or... you could just press the "Open in Customizer" button and design one to fit your own swimming goggles.
Just print out the thing using best resolution (layer height) possible and 70-90% infill.

Hi everybody, I am from Villa Castelli, a tiny village which belongs to Apulia, a region in the southern part of Italy. In my area there is a typical construction called 'trullo' which is a traditional Apulian dry stone hut with a conical roof. Trulli were generally constructed as temporary field shelters and storehouses or as permanent dwellings by small proprietors or agricultural labourers. They are very famous in the city of Alberobello, and in general in the Itria Valley.

I am proud of my region and its traditions, so I decided to enter this challenge with this small building, which is the symbol of my beautiful region.

See: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trullo about the Trullo and its history...

...And: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apulia about the beautiful region where I live.

author: Namiokubo

title: DJI Phantom 3 iPad Mini Sun Visor

description.text:
Sun visor for iPad Mini. I designed this for use with the DJI Phantom 3 RC unit with the built-in adjustable phone/tablet holder. The iPad Mini (all versions are the same size) slides into the visor and the whole thing is then clamped onto the DJI RC unit. The idea for this design was to make it light weight, so the walls of the visor are only 1mm thick (as designed). The actual resulting thickness from my printer is about 1.15mm. Also, there are cutouts for the USB/Lightning cable and the power switch. Note that the iPad is mounted with the power switch on the right and is about half obscured by the visor to make it harder to hit accidentally. You can use your thumbnail to activate the switch.
This remix by jcampen looks like a good improvement: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:981087 It is beefed up in some of the weaker places. My original design was an attempt to make it as light weight as possible -- I haven't broken it yet, but one wrong hit and I'm sure it could break.
New comment: After a few months since I designed this, I used it in some very hot weather and because it is thin and made of PLA, it starts to warp in direct sunlight on hot days. When it does, I have simply formed it back into shape by hand while it's still hot from the sun. Although it is warped, mostly on the top face, it still works. I'm surprised it hasn't broken. It might help to print it in a more reflective color to keep it from getting so hot in direct sunlight. Or print in ABS to stand up to slightly higher temperatures.

I printed in black PLA with .25mm thick layers, 20% fill.
Trim off the 'Mickey Mouse' ears (which are there to keep the corners of the print from warping up), from the outside of the top-rear corners after printing the visor (unless you're a fan of Mickey Mouse).

comments.text: The large circles protruding off the rear make it just too big to print on my bed.  Good design but it would be nice if they weren't there.
comments.author: RobFra

comments.text: Thanks for you deign. its a nice print overall. Just seems a bit tight and one side split when sliding the iPad mini in and out. Perhaps some reinforcing is needed around the edge where it slides in would be good. I'll look at adding some later and do a reprint.  Also the socket was to high so I had to cut it out a bit lower. I printed it in ABS 1mm shell and 20% fill density. The top of the shade bows down a little, but its not an issue. I also left the ears on because I found it makes it easier to pull it off.
comments.author: jcampen

comments.text: My print was a very tight fit and I had to do a small amount of careful carving of the overhanging rail restraining parts to get the iPad Mini to slide in, so yes, it could use some revision, maybe just scaling it up to 102% or so would do it. I made this thin -- designed to be light weight, not strong -- could easily break, but I haven't broken mine -- yet.
comments.author: jcampen

comments.text: I posted my remix. It has thickened sides just around the areas on the sides where the iPad slots in. I also cut the bottom cross brace and put velcro on there so the tightness can be adjusted. It printed out really nicely.
comments.author: tetralite

comments.text: Nice job. Beefing up the higher stress points is a good idea.
comments.author: jcampen

title: Folding Poster/Shelves
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
"Tableau pliant / Ã©tagÃ¨re d'appoint"
Plenty of pictures here : http://flic.kr/s/aHsjvcr15A And a vid here : http://youtu.be/SoM2HjQwqPU That's one of the 4 finalist project of the Unlimited Design Contest 2011
http://unlimiteddesigncontest.org/fr/product/tableau-pliant-%C3%A9tag%C3%A8re-dappoint It's a folding system, allowing to create structures, from the small shelve to the huge book-shelve (whether we use foam-core light cardboard or heavy cardboard with triple ondulation). Many variations are possible, just take care when altering the 2D plan cause any modifications will impact the 3D folded structure. The surface is optimized to avoid almost any wastes, and both states of the object (folded or not) are exploited : when folded it's a shelve, and when flat its eventually a poster or a painting (that's will be very practical for when you have to move) The grid-unit system allows to apply this concept to different scales. Just don't forget to to adjust the notch corresponding to the thickness of the material chosen. The example on the left filled with books and dvds was made in foamcore board, and can support a weight of 6kg with only 6-8 pins! Used since 2007 and still good :)

• All the designs are based on a grid system, thus you can scale the model to fit your material or any size you want (700x430mm in my case when I lasercutted the last versions). Just adjust the notch for material thickness.
  • Lasercut
  • Hang with some pins or small nails
    • You can also made it by hand, that's how I made the first models, it's just a little longer.
    Start by scaling/tracing the grid on your material, then use the grid to trace the blueprint. Next, carefully cut the lines and the folding lines (I often cut a fold, in that case a piece of tape is a good fix). Caution, void attract things naturally, especially for empty shelves :) Files are named by
    Number Of Tabs (eventually framed)
    Dimension Of The Grid (number of squares)
    Dimension Of One Square In mm (scale as you want)

This box is 40x20x10mm with 10mm circular hole in middle. I prefer this calibration cube to the standard 20mm cube because its easier to see what axis is what and also the hole in middle helps in assessing if holes get printed correctly
Adapter for a noctua fan (with rubber damping) to standard Intel I5 (and more?) standard heat sink.
I really liked Tiki-Tourist's card holder, but my printer kept making a mess of the hexes in the middle. Simple solution... remove them.

I havn't seen somebody doing this so I started to work out alle the .stl out of the .psk game files from Killing Floor 2.
As far as the new Update(s) come I will update the weapon-asylum with new .stl
Feel free to message me if you have some ideas or problems with the files.
Have fun and keep killing Zeds!

The models as .psk game files use unreal units as measurements. As defined in the unreal engine one unreal unit correspondends to one centimeter.

All weapons are in "life size", means one unreal unit was converted to one centimeter. If you want to print a file "as is" you may need to divide it in 2 or more parts, depending on your printer and building volume.

For knifes or other smaller weapons I suggest to print with 100% infill.
For rifles you could try 3 shells and 20% infill with honeycombs or 25% linear infill.
Feel free to experiment with the settings to get the best results for your purposes.
Try to print a small part first to test see how the print structure works, so you dont waste material.

Enjoy printing and please share your results if you print something, I would love to see that!

Replacement head for Ultimaker to allow the use of the E3D hotend.
This allows jam free printing at elevated temperatures for PLA, ABS and PC. It can also go phenominally fast. ABS at >150mm/s is no problem, as you can run it at 265deg. This also gives very strong parts with superb surface finish.
It has mounting points that replicate the lower Ultimaker plate, so as you can attach your favorite cooling fan. The E3D head is held in with a single screw and captive nut.
YouTube link of my first version printing here http://youtu.be/5YNZmCaw0O4. Apologies for the poor camera work!
With thanks to Sanjay at E3D for his support! Please see the fanduct optimised for this head
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:131647

Print both parts top and bottom in ABS, no supports needed, and stick them together with acetone or superglue or print the whole thing at once with supports if you prefer.
If (like me) your printer can't do ABS with the V2 hotend, then make one in PLA, and it will last long enough to make one in ABS that should last. Depending on how well calibrated your Ultimaker is, you may need to clean out the 12mm diameter holes for the linear bearings with a reamer, or it actually works quite well just to paint them with acetone to soften the inner surface before you push the bearings in. The ABS then sets around the bearings. All parts are assembled with M3 screws. The Ultimaker thermocouple board screws directly on top. The wires from the fan, heater and thermocouple go up the tube on the head to keep them neat. This works well in a heated chamber up to about 45degC, above that the cold end of the head can't be kept cold enough. This is normally warm enough to stop ABS from warping though, so shouldn't be a problem. You will need to adjust your endstop switches slightly, the size of the head means you lose about 2mm of X and Y area. Z height is the same as the V2 ultimkaker head. Any questions just message me or post on here.

comments.text: It seems that keeping the bottom most fins cool will prevent the heat from creeping up the stainless steel heat break. Other E3D mounts have the fan as far down as possible relative to those fins. Your design is by far the most solid and stable but I believe that I'm having issues with PLA sticking/jamming because it is getting hot too far up the heat break. Would you consider making the whole assembly taller and shifting the fan mounting holes down to cool the bottom fins? Thanks for all your hard work.
comments.author: GhettoFabulousEngineering

comments.text:
Hi, The fan position is based on the position of the fan on E3D's own duct. It has the bottom of the fan level with the lowest heatsink fin, so it is hard to see it going any lower, without getting too close to the hot parts. You don't want the fan air to escape below the heatsink and cool the heater block.
The data is posted in STEP format, which most CAD systems can use, so please feel free to mod and report mack if you can get an improvement.

Andrew

This model shows the helix parametrized by x=cos(t), y=sin(t), z=t for t=0 to t=5pi.

There are several print options: the helix can be thick or think, and have the equations imprinted on it or not.

This model was designed and printed by my WLU summer research student Ryan McDonnell ('17).

We printed both helices on the FormLabs Form 1+ printer. The thin helix (with equations) was printed in black. It is really fine, with diameter about 2mm and is almost too delicate. The regular helix (with equations) was printed in white. It is quite robust, though the equations are hard to see. We recommend printing in grey resin to see the equations clearly. The .form file is included for the black thin helix.

title: T4 mini 250 FPV camera elevation gimbal

description.text:
Elevation gimbal made for the T4 mini. Sure it will work on lots of other platforms too. I put more holes than required for the mini T4 just to have options for other quads later. Makes flying much easier than when I was constantly looking at the ground or the sky.

https://youtu.be/9RS_8K2dbnI
Camera box remixed from

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:840385

Servo arm is remix of one I found in thingiverse, that I can't seem to find.

Build parts with .2mm layers 40% infill PLA.
Servo arm (due to splines) was built .05mm layer 50% normal speed and100% fill.
I am using currently a CC3D controller. I have set the angle range to +-22.5deg.
The camera AND tx is very cheap ($26) and very good from Bangood.
http://us.banggood.com/Wholesale-Warehouse-Eachine-700TVL-13-Cmos-FPV-110-Degree-Camera-w32CH-Transmission-wp-Usa-965760.html

Servo is from Amazon
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00CCZ2CRA?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00
UPDATE 8/6/15
WARNING DO NOT GET THESE SERVOS! They are junk. Buy a good one. I had a motor our condition at 100' of alt. the other day. When did an accident investigation afterward I found the this servo shorted internally witch caused the flight board output to the ESC's to drop out. Quads do not glide. Fortunately no bought parts were destroyed outside of 1 prop. All but 2 printed parts were all a complete loss.

Control link I had a .047" music wire laying around. You can use up to 1.25mm-1.5mm should work good too.

comments.text: hi , say have you tried this out yet? if so does it work keeping the signal better? as in there should be less glitching when you tilt but what about when you bank? you need a dual servo is all to do that but my question stands is it better than it was? thanks ps try out the left handed polarity airblades for perfect pictures.
comments.author: tommy2toes

comments.text: Yes, gimbal works fantastic. I can fly much more aggressively than with a fixed camera looking at the ground or sky most of the time. Flew with it everyday all last summer. Finally played with my expo rates so I don't have at tons of throttle going into forward fight. Gets bit deceptive looking at the horizon when you are losing alt. I like seeing the bank when I turn. Really don't notice a difference in signal quality. I previously had a fixed transmitter box of the same design on the same quad. Haven't noticed a difference between the two. Tried tons of different antennas, cheap-expensive. Best signal quality bar none was these cheap ass 5.8-2.4 combo antennas (shown). Have them on all my FPV now.

description.text:
Since my printer is a small bed printer, I had to design something that I could print it out.

This can be used for both A+ and B+ Raspberry pi and can be also used for 75mm and 100mm VESA Mount.

The design is made to fit 4mm screws for TV and 3mm screws and nuts for the Raspberry pi.

The holes are a little bit tight fit. Those holes are made with a 2.4 mm diameter.

https://youtu.be/_c7xG77Zbw0

Hope it is useful for someone out there.

Has anyone downloaded any file? It seems to be a problem when I try to upload it. Please feel free to tell me.

UPDATE 1

I'm having problems uploading the files so here is a link to my drive so you can download it.

https://drive.google.com/open?id=0B7dtMeeMPK5rfmxoOFlmSTVHZ1BDSExzQVJ5dk5VX3dyQWFUcWhHWkdrdDV5WkdxUzIxeWs

I have added to de design some standoff because when I place the Raspberry Pi on the mount it wasn't level.

The file is called Ver2_Raspberry_VESA_Mount.stl

It has all four parts for the VESA mount. It is still suitable for 75mm and 100mm VESA mount.

description.text:
Designed to fit the Matego MG380G and a Toyota Tacoma windshield, but should fit other applications.

Ball is 16mm.
Windshield angle is 57 degrees.

There are lots of interesting cubic curves in the world. They're interesting because with just 4 points, you can describe very interesting shapes. These curves make for nice revolutionary solids, but with OpenScad, it's kind of a challenge. This thing generalizes the surface of revolution based on a cubic curve. How simple is it? The following will generate that bell shaped picture based on a Catmull-Rom cubic curve. surface_rotationx_cubic(anglesteps = 36, stacksteps = 12,
umult = 0.5, A = cubic_catmullrom_M(),
cps = [[0, 1, 0],[2,3,0], [4,1,0],[5,2,0]]); And this one will do the same for a standard Bezier curve based on the same control points surface_rotationx_cubic(anglesteps = 24, stacksteps = 12,
umult = 1, A = cubic_bezier_M(),
cps = [[0, 1, 0],[2,3,0], [4,1,0],[5,2,0]]); And the same can be done for a Hermite, or any other 'cubic' curve you can think of. The two key components are the blending function 'A', which is a 4x4 matrix, and the control points 'cps', which are simply the geometry of your control points. The routine, found in the revolids.scad file, will take care of all the dirty work. I marked this as version '0.5' because although it will show pretty pictures, right now it's not doing the surface normal calculations, or anything else really necessary to make solids, so a couple more iterations. But, it's fun to play with. I've really been wracking my brain on the lack of function pointers in OpenScad, but this essentially provides the same capability, utilizing the matrices, which are the essence of these things anyway. At any rate, something to play with. UPDATE: 220611
Added a picture of a Hermite revolid with debugging normals (showing the circular normals to be incorrect).

1) Download all the .scad files
2) Fiddle about with the test_revolids.scad to make pretty pictures
3) Rejoice!

author: sjm

description.text:
Part of a Stereo starting unit triggered by AppleTv

When you start AppleTV via Airplay on your phone, the stereo will automatically turn on.

Arduino (uno) reads status of the Apple TV LED and Turns stereo ON and OFF accordingly via IR transmitter.

The IR programming is done once by pressing a button on the unit and directing your remote towards it and press (multiple) commands of choice (example ON/OFF and channel input)

remixed_from.author: Dhart
remixed_from.title: Suncast Hose Reel RSH125 replacement handle.

description.text:
Suncast Hose Reel RSH125

This is a remix/remake of: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:165144

NEW and IMPROVED

  1. Part is now one solid body
  2. Seriously heavy duty
  3. Passes all mesh tests
  4. Slices properly and works!

Comparrison

I printed the other thing with ABS at 80% fill and it snapped into three pieces with little force.

This Version

I Printed this handle with PLA at 20% (for an initial test print) and it was much stronger. Strong enough to put it in service as is.

Special notes

The handle doesn't snap on like the original, it is so close, it fits nicely though and the cover holds it in place perfectly.

Also, it is highly likely that your original handle broke because of friction on the inner seals. This is super easy to fix. Remove the three screws on the white part under where the handle goes. Use some silicone lube or some grease on the rubber rings and just inside the black tube. Reassemble and it will operate as it should.

remixed_from.author: brackett27
remixed_from.title: Replicator 2 Top Mount Filament Spool Holder/Dispenser

title: Replicator 2 Top Mount Filament Spool Holder/Dispenser Upper Deck

description.text: So this is derived from my original spool holder (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:74050) and is an add on. I recently purchased some PLA from MatterHackers (https://www.matterhackers.com/) and the Pro series spools had centers that were only 0.75in diameter. They would not fit on my previous design as my spools were not wide enough and they had end flanges that would not fit through the MatterHackers spool. So I designed a simple tube to replace them. I then decided that I wanted as many of my colors as were manageble to be mounted on the the printer. So I took the lower design and modded it to add a second tier. There are a few other additions that make this a better print than the lower one. Things like breakaway tabs to prevent some bridging issues in places. It all seems pretty stable and it cleaned up my workspace a bunch!

As with the bottoms you need to print a left and right tower. You should also print some spools as they act as bearing surfaces for your PLA spools. Break out the tabs that are in the top shaft area and the one for the clearance at the bottom. If you are using blue tape I have found that if you rough it up with a little sandpaper you can get rid of most of the curl in any print. Yes it makes it harder to get off but it stays on the build plate. I used a 3/8 x 36in threaded rod (Home Depot) and supporting hardware which includes 2 nuts that seat in the towers, see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:74050 for how that works. You will need some nuts at the ends of the rods as well. I used self tapping sheet metal screws to put them together. There are 5 of those per tower. When you put them together you will hear a lot of crackling noises from the screws. I am pretty sure that is just the interior fill engaging with the screw. But if you printed your bottom with the 5 shells there will be about 1/8 of material to get purchase for the screw. Sometime I will revise the bottom so there are holes there to start with. Print Settings: Shells 5 (this is a must!)
Layer 0.34mm
Fill 10% One more item of note, there is one issue to be aware of with this incarnation, and that is that the lower rod will now require you to remove the screws to gain access to change the spools in the middle. I am thinking of ways to change that in a future design.

comments.author: fahadalawam

comments.text: how do you guys find the PLA and exposure to moisture?
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: New Mexico desert here.
Utah here. Great american desert. Moisture? What moisture?

I guess it depends on your environment and how fast you use the filament. My spaces tend to be dry.  Occasionally when loading I see some steam from that but I have not noticed it during prints. I will say that nylon soaks up a bunch of moisture and actually crackles when printing.  I suggest you might bake out and desiccate the nylon before use if you are using that.
dont you have issues of filament getting entangled....??
comments.author: ekaggrat

comments.text: It has never happened.  Actually the contrary.  When I was hanging on the back sometimes the filament would slip off the reel somehow and bind up around the spindle holding the reel.  I have yet to see that happen in this setup.  I do keep a 2kg spool of black on the back [back in black :)] and run it over the top of the lower center reel and have had not problems there either.  It just works.
comments.author: ekaggrat

comments.text: That looks so crazy! Awesome! BTW... All the weight on the back plane does put the bot off balance a bit. I was thinking about simply putting a second rod on the front. Your original design is one of the best upgrades I've done to my Rep2 THANKS!!
comments.author: TobyCWood

comments.text: So I tired a tipping test with it fully loaded.   Mind you I still have a 5lb spool of black on the backside too.  I just drape the black over one of the other spools which then acts like a pulley  You have to lift the front of the printer at least an inch for it to start to go over.  Considering I never do that it should not be an issue.  I had considered putting a set on the front but decided that getting to the extruder would be made more difficult.  So I opted for this instead.
